thread.title: 'Stangs stampede Lynx, clinch coveted postseason berth
thread.title_full: 'Stangs stampede Lynx, clinch coveted postseason berth

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Mark Haskell)
title: 'Stangs stampede Lynx, clinch coveted postseason berth
text:
'Stangs stampede Lynx, clinch coveted postseason berth Mount View eyes home playoff game with Oct. 20 win over Washington Academy By Mark Haskell | Oct 19, 2015 
Lincoln — To say that the Friday night, Oct. 16 high school football game for Mount View was an important one would be an understatement. 
Not only would a win over host Mattanawcook Academy lock the Mustangs in for a playoff spot, it would put them in prime position to host a home postseason game. 
On the heels of an impressive 33-18 win over the Lynx, the Mustangs now are halfway home, so to speak. 
While Mount View has secured a playoff spot, if it can beat Washington Academy (2-5) at home on Saturday, Oct. 24, the Mustangs will secure a home playoff game. 
Mattanawcook Academy held a 12-7 lead at halftime of Friday's game, but it “would prove to be a tale of two halves,” said Mustang coach Harold "Haggie" Pratt. 
Cole Hannan completed one pass on the day — a 17-yard touchdown connection to Tyler Ripley. 
Leading the Mount View offense on the ground were Ripley (22 carries for 121 yards, 3 TDs), Darrin Cook (12 carries for 116 yards), Jack Axsom (8 carries for 79 yards, TD), Hannan (3 carries for 8 yards) and Devon Davis (carry for 7 yards). 
The Mustang offense totaled 331 yards on the ground. 
On defense, the 'Stangs were paced by Ethan Sewell-Berry (5 solo tackles, 8 assisted tackles, fumble recovery), Ben Rodgers (11 solos, 3 assists), Casey Spaulding (6 solos, 4 assists), Ripley (3 solos, 4 assists), Axsom (5 solos, 2 assists), Hannan (6 solos, assist, interception), Gavin Simpson (5 solos, 2 assists), Davis (5 solos, assist, fumble recovery), Seth Talbot (solo, 5 assists), Justin Lizotte (2 assists), Liam Cail (2 assists), Alex Bennett (2 assists), Colton Medina (solo, assist) and Raino Boivin (solo, assist, fumble recovery). 
After Cook returned the opening kick into Mattanawcook Academy territory, Ripley capped the drive and the visitors did not trail again the rest of the contest. 
The Lynx were in position to take a lead as they drove the ball to the Mount View 1-yard line, but Sewell-Berry forced and recovered a fumble, which started a 99-yard scoring drive — capped by another score by Ripley. 
Davis then recovered another fumble on the ensuing kickoff, which Mount View turned into another quick score. 
The Lynx answered with a touchdown, but Mount View produced a methodical drive, which culminated with another score with just over two minutes to play in the game. 
Now, the 'Stangs turn their attention to the Huskies — and a shot to bring playoff football back to Thorndike. 
“If we can pull off a win this weekend, it is possible for us to finish the season in second place,” said Pratt. “Washington Academy knocked us out of the playoffs two years ago and we cannot afford to overlook them this weekend. They have a good fullback and several good receivers. They always play Mount View tough and we're expecting another tough game this Saturday.” 
In the Maine Principals' Association Crabtree Point Standings for Class D North, Mount View (5-2, 123.9714 points) is third, while Maine Central Institute (7-0, 148.2143 points) is first in the 12-team region.
